headline: CNN Special Reports
subHeadline: America Coup: The January 6th Investigation Special. Aired 10- 11p ET

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: President Elect Biden and hold hearings and basically had the state legislatures pick a new slate of electors.

utterances.speaker: JAKE TAPPER, CNN HOST
utterances.sentences: That a letter claimed that the U.S. Department of Justice's investigations have, "Identified significant concerns that may have impacted the outcome of the election in multiple states including the State of Georgia." Was that true?

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: No.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: While the letter was sent solely by Jeff Clark, it was written with the help of a new Justice Department employee named, Ken Klukowski, who, according to the committee, was also working with John Eastman, the architect of the multi-step plan to overturn the election. The letter mirrored some of Eastman's unconstitutional theories.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Would have created chaos in the States. I think that would have been disastrous for our country and our Constitution.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: But wasn't that the point of it, the letter to create that casts?

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: I think so. Yes.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: Disturbed by the letter, Donoghue immediately responded to Clark writing, quote, "This would be a grave step for the department to take. And it could have tremendous constitutional, political, and social ramifications for the country."

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: I had to make it clear to him that there was no world in which I and certainly the AG, we're going to sign a letter like that.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: Rosen and Donoghue met with Clark later that evening.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: I do remember at the very end, saying to him, what you're proposing is nothing less than having the United States Justice Department meddle in the outcome of an American presidential election.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: But again, Jeffrey Clark ignored the direction of Justice Department leadership. He continued to claim falsely that there was widespread election fraud. He pushed to send out the letter again. And on January 3rd, he told Rosen, President Trump had offered him the role of Attorney General. And he had accepted.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: And that led to a series of discussions and meetings that day. At this point, it had gone so far that we had to bring other leaders in and explain to them so they were prepared in case it happened, but also to get their take on what they would do if that did happen.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: And what did they say they would do?

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: They uniformly said they were resigned.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: White House call logs obtained by the committee show that by 4That evening, Rosen and Donoghue went to the White House to argue against Trump installing Clark as Attorney General. The three-hour meeting took place in the Oval Office, and by all accounts, joined the long list of wild White House meetings.

utterances.speaker: JEFFREY ROSEN, FORMER UNITED STATES DEPUTY ATTORNEY GENERAL
utterances.sentences: The president turned to me and he said, well, one thing we know is you, Rosen, you aren't going to do anything. You don't even agree with the claims of election fraud. And this other guy, at least, might do something.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: It was basically Jeff Clark advocating for the leadership change and everyone else advocating against it. It was a very blunt, contentious conversation.Herschmann and I were on the same level of being sort of the street fighters of the meeting.

utterances.speaker: ERIC HERSCHMANN, FORMER WHITE HOUSE SENIOR ADVISOR
utterances.sentences: When he finished discussing what he planned on doing, I said, good fucking -- excuse me, sorry effing deal. Congratulations, you just admitted the first step or act you take as attorney general will be committing a felony and violating Rule 6A 60. You're clearly the right candidate for this job.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: White House Counsel, Pat Cipollone, was vehemently against the plan as well.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: He referred to the letter that Jeff Clark had submitted as a murder suicide pact, that no one should have anything to do with it. I had basically made the point that the President Jeff Clark was not even qualified to be the Attorney General.He's promising you he's going to conduct these very complex, nationwide investigations in record time. And this is coming from a guy who's never conducted a real investigation. Mr. Clark responded by saying that he's been involved in very significant environmental law briefing before various courts. And that reminded me that, yes, in fact, you're primarily, you're an environmental lawyer. How about you go back to your office and we'll call you when there's an oil spill?

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: Donoghue, also informed President Trump that upon Clark's appointment, Justice Department leaders would resign on mass.STEVEN ENGEL, FORMER U.S. ASSISTANT GENERAL: The president turned to me and said, Steve, you wouldn't leave, would you? I said, Mr. President, I've been with you through four attorneys general, including two acting's Attorney General, but I couldn't be part of this.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: Finally persuaded Trump decided against the idea. When Clark was subpoenaed by the January 6 Committee earlier this year, he refused to answer questions pleading the fifth more than 125 times.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Did you discuss this draft letter to Georgia officials with the president of the United States?

utterances.speaker: JEFFREY CLARK, FORMER ASSISTANT ATTORNEY GENERAL
utterances.sentences: Fifth.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: On December 14th, 2020 --

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: Unanimously cast 16 votes for Joseph R. Biden.(APPLAUSE)

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: When the electors in each state gathered --

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: All 16 electors cast their ballots for Joseph R. Biden.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: So did fraudulent electors in seven swing states that Biden had won, such as Arizona.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: Donald J. Trump of his state of Florida number of votes, 11.

utterances.speaker: STEPHEN MILLER, TRUMP CAMPAIGN SENIOR ADVISER
utterances.sentences: And ultimate slate of electors in the contested states is going to vote and we're going to send those results up to Congress.This desperate scheme to overthrow the election results had been conceived weeks earlier.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Who do you remember being involved in those early discussions around the Thanksgiving time? Regarding having alternate electors meet? UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: One of the biggest supporters of this outrageous attempt to subvert American democracy was law professor and Trump Attorney, John Eastman.

utterances.speaker: JOHN EASTMAN, FORMER DONALD TRUMP ATTORNEY
utterances.sentences: The entire executive branch is headed by one guy.

utterances.speaker: KAITLAN COLLINS, CNN HOST
utterances.sentences: Trump saw him on Fox News. And shortly after that, he was in the Oval Office.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: What you can do is you can say, due to these disputes in these seven states, we're going to send this back to the states and the states would then be able to help Donald Trump win the election.

utterances.speaker: LIZ CHENEY, FORMER UNITED STATES REPRESENTATIVE
utterances.sentences: It was a lie. In fact, on December 19th 2020, just four days before Dr. Eastman sent this memo, Dr. Eastman himself admitted, in an e-mail, that the fake electors had no legal weight. Referring to the fake electors is, quote, "dead on arrival in Congress."

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: Trump campaign aides and outside lawyers shared their concerns about the scheme in e-mails, reported on by the New York Times' Maggie Haberman and Luke Broadwater.And did they think what they were doing was legal?

utterances.speaker: MAGGIE HABERMAN, SENIOR POLITICAL CORRESPONDENT, NEW YORK TIMES
utterances.sentences: And one e-mail lawyer working in Arizona literally describes them as quote, unquote, fake electors. He says, wo what we would be doing is sending these fake electors he has taken quotes to go cast ballots.In another e-mail, there was a discussion about fear from some officials. This would be seen as quote-unquote, treasonous.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: What might have happened had Pence trying to go through with this idea that he could reject electoral votes and send them back to the states Biden won such as Arizona, Pennsylvania, Wisconsin, Georgia.

utterances.speaker: LUTTIG
utterances.sentences: A, would have immediately plunged the country into what I characterized would be tantamount to a revolution within a paralyzing constitutional crisis. GREG JACOB, FORMER LEGAL COUNSEL TO PENCEThere was no way that they would have put in the hands of one person the authority to determine who was going to be President of the United States.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: But president Trump now saw vice president Pence as the man who could keep him in the White House for four more years.REP. PETER AGUILAR (D-CA): On December 23rd, President Trump retweeted a memo from an individual named, Ivan Raiklin, entitled Operation Pence Card that called on the vice president to refuse the Electoral College votes from certain states that had certified Joe Biden is the winner.

utterances.speaker: EVAN PEREZ, CNN SENIOR JUSTICE CORRESPONDENT
utterances.sentences: He had been pressuring him behind the scenes. So now, he's going public, he's trying to get public pressure on Mike Pence.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: The January 6 Committee's interviews with White House attorneys made it clear that Pat Cipollone, Eric Herschmann, and many others were appalled.

utterances.speaker: JASON MILLER, FORMER TRUMP CAMPAIGN SENIOR ADVISOR
utterances.sentences: The way it was communicated to me it was that Pat Cipollone thought the idea was nutty. And had at what point confronted Eastman, basically with the same sentiment.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: What were your prior interactions with Eastman?

utterances.speaker: HERSCHMANN
utterances.sentences: He described for me what he thought the ambiguity was in the statute. And he was walking through it at that time. And I said, hold on a second. I want to understand what you're saying. You're saying that you believe the vice president, acting as president of the Senate, can be the sole decision maker as to under your theory, who becomes the next president of the United States?And he said, yes. I said, are you out of your effing mind?

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: The vice president decided he could not buy in to Eastman's theories.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Mr. Short, was it your impression that the vice president had directly conveyed his position on these issues to the president?

utterances.speaker: MARC SHORT, FORMER CHIEF OF STAFF TO VICE PRESIDENT MIKE PENCE
utterances.sentences: Many times.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: And had been consistent in conveying his position to the president?

utterances.speaker: SHORT
utterances.sentences: Very consistent. COLLINS

utterances.speaker: DONALD TRUMP, FORMER PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES
utterances.sentences: I hope that our great vice president, our great vice president, comes through for us. He's a great guy. Because if he doesn't come through, I won't like him for this much.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: That night, Pence's outside lawyer, Richard Cullen, phoned retired judge, Michael Luttig, an esteemed conservative Republican, for help and advice.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: Why did you take to Twitter?

utterances.speaker: LUTTIG
utterances.sentences: Well, the next morning Richard calls and he said, look, we have to get your voice out to the country immediately within the next hour to --

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: Judge Luttig, with the help of his son, sent his first-ever Twitter thread.

utterances.speaker: LUTTIG
utterances.sentences: My son sent me Twitter instructions on how to tweet a thread of individual tweets that were under 100 and 140 care. And I had no earthly idea what any of this was about. I just told my son, send it to me right now or I'll cut you out of the will.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: He read me some of that thread.

utterances.speaker: LUTTIG
utterances.sentences: The only responsibility and power of the vice president, under the Constitution, is to faithfully count the Electoral College votes as they had been cast. The Constitution does not empower the vice president to alter in any way the votes that had been cast, either by rejecting certain of them or otherwise.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: That Twitter thread spread and garnered attention around the world. But with just one day, before Congress was set to certify Biden's Electoral College victory, Trump continued to apply maximum pressure.In this tweet, quote, the vice president has the power to reject fraudulently chosen electors. And when they met at the White House, on January 5th.

utterances.speaker: AGUILAR
utterances.sentences: In the book, "Peril" journalist, Bob Woodward and Robert Costa, write that the president said quote, if these people say you have the power, wouldn't you want to? The vice president says, I wouldn't want any one person to have that authority. The president says no, no, no, you don't understand, Mike. You can do this. I don't want to be your friend anymore. If you don't do this.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: Trump would not relent at 1And then there was the morning phone call, in which the president bullied and belittled the vice president for refusing to go along with this potential coup.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: I don't remember he said you are wimp, you'll be a wimp. Wimp is the word I remember.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: It's also been reported that the president said to the vice president that something to the effect that you don't have the courage to make a hard decision.

utterances.speaker: KEITH KELLOG, FORMER PENCE NATIONAL SECURITY ADVISOR
utterances.sentences: Worse. I don't remember Jeff needed with something like that. Yes.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: Soon after the call ended, Trump would repeat his dangerous lies and put a target on vice president Pence.

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: I hope Mike is going to do the right thing. I hope so. And Mike Pence is going to have to come through for us.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: As that speech neared its end, inside the Capitol --

utterances.speaker: MIKE PENCE, FORMER VICE PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES
utterances.sentences: The Senate and House of Representatives are meeting a joint session to verify the certificates and count the votes of the electors.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: But outside, headed their way.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: There are thousands of people here already this line wraps around the Washington and the president is scheduled to speak and --

utterances.speaker: CASSIDY HUTCHINSON, FORMER ASSISTANT TOO WHITE HOUSE CHIEF OF STAFF MARK MEADOWS
utterances.sentences: As Mr. Giuliani and I were walking to his vehicles that evening, he looked at me and said something to the effect of, Cass, are you excited for the 6th? We're going to the Capitol. It's going to be great. President's going to be there. He's going to look powerful.(CHANTING "STOP THE STEAL")

utterances.speaker: CHENEY
utterances.sentences: On January 3rd, the Capitol Police issued a special event assessment. Congress itself is the target on the 6th.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Now, we're on as they say the point of attack.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: Listen to what Mr. Bannon said that day after the first call he had with the President.

utterances.speaker: STEVE BANNON, FORMER WHITE HOUSE CHIEF STRATEGIST
utterances.sentences: All hell is going to break loose tomorrow. All I can say is strap in.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: They thought they could steal this election.

utterances.speaker: SARA MURRAY, CNN POLITICAL CORRESPONDENT
utterances.sentences: And then he had Donald Trump talk again. And we don't know what the contents of those calls were because, of course, Donald Trump has not provided that information. And Steve Bannon has not provided that information.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: The night of January 5th, you were among those summoned to the Oval Office.

utterances.speaker: SARAH MATTHEWS, FORMER WHITE HOUSE DEPUTY PRESS SECRETARY FOR TRUMP
utterances.sentences: Yes. So I was brought into the Oval Office that evening, and the entire press team was assembled in there.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: The gates opened just a few minutes ago.

utterances.speaker: MATTHEWS
utterances.sentences: The President had the door to the Rose Garden open. And you could hear the crowd on the lips already assembled. And you could tell he was feeding off that energy. And that he was really excited for the next day.

utterances.speaker: SHEALAH CRAIGHEAD, FORMER TRUMP WHITE HOUSE PHOTOGRAPHER
utterances.sentences: The president was making notes that talking then about we should go to the Capitol, what's the best route to go to the Capitol.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: The January 6 Committees presentation of testimony and documentation left no doubt that Trump had every intention of joining his supporters marched to the Capitol.(CHANTING "FIGHT FOR TRUMP")

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Did the president tell you this that he wanted to speak at the Capitol?

utterances.speaker: NICK LUNA, FORMER ASSISTANT TO THE PRESIDENT
utterances.sentences: Correct, yes.(CHANTING "STOP THE STEAL")

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: We have the power in numbers. We came here to protect our republic.(CHANTING "FIGHT FOR TRUMP")

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: The morning of January 6th.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: USA.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: You will listen to him.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: USA.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: Supporters began gathering for the rally.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: Biden did not win this election.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: What do you think happened?

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: Fraud

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: It's not made-up.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: Meanwhile, the president's insistence on joining their march to the Capitol --

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: And White House lawyers such as Pat Cipollone very worried.

utterances.speaker: HUTCHINSON
utterances.sentences: Mr. Cipollone said something to the effect of, please make sure we don't go up to the Capitol, Cassidy. Keep in touch with me.(CHANTING "BULLSHIT")

utterances.speaker: HUTCHINSON
utterances.sentences: We're going to get charged with every crime imaginable if we make that movement happen.(CHANTING "FIGHT FOR TRUMP")

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: But nobody could change Trump's mind.And as he family and aides arrived at the rally, his chief of staff, Mark Meadows, was keeping the president's hopes alive.

utterances.speaker: HUTCHINSON
utterances.sentences: Prior to Mr. Trump taking the stage that morning, he was under the impression by Mr. Meadows that it was still possible.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: At the rally, the president had a more immediate familiar concern, crowd size.

utterances.speaker: HUTCHINSON
utterances.sentences: We were in the off stage, and that's very a tent behind the stage. He was very concerned about the shot.(CHANTING "USA")

utterances.speaker: MURRAY
utterances.sentences: For the pictures that were shared, he wanted to make sure that the rally space was full. And so he's being told, it's not that people are waiting to get through these mags through these metal detectors. People don't want to go through them because they have weapons with them.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: During the hearings, the Select Committee showed a Secret Service report that, quote, "Some members of the crowd are wearing ballistic helmets, body armor, and carrying radio equipment and military grade backpacks."

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: Let's Listen.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: The committee also played police radio transmissions from that day.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: And the individual was answering. He's got a blue jeans and a blue jean jacket. And underneath the blue jean jacket is blue pants both saw and stocked with AR-15. And we went the group of individuals about (inaudible) other individuals, two of the individuals in that group, they had Glock-style pistols in their waist.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: I've got three men walking down the street in fatigues carrying AR-15s. Copy at 14th and Independence.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: Yet, Trump wanted the metal detectors, the magnetometers or MAGS, removed.

utterances.speaker: HUTCHINSON
utterances.sentences: Well, if you're the offstage announced tent, I was in the vicinity of a conversation where I ever heard the president say something to the effect of, you know, I don't -- I think that they have weapons. They're not here to hurt me. Take the effing mags away. Let my people end it and march the Capitol from here. Let the people in and take the effing mags away.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Ladies and gentlemen, the 45th president of the United States of America --(CHEERING)

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: -- Donald J. Trump.

utterances.speaker: CHENEY
utterances.sentences: Let's reflect on that for a moment. President Trump was aware that a number of the individuals in the crowd had weapons and were wearing body armor. And here's what President Trump instructed the crowd to do.

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: We're going to walk down and I'll be there with you. We're going to walk down any one you want, but I think right here, we're going to walk down to the Capitol to peacefully and patriotically make your voices heard.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: How would you characterize Donald Trump's speech at the ellipse on January 6th?

utterances.speaker: HABERMAN
utterances.sentences: Inciting. He said peacefully and patriotically that he was telling people go up there. And it's hard not to see that that was fomenting and telling people that he had been harmed, and they should be angry on his behalf.

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: You'll never take back our country with weakness. You have to show strength and you have to be strong.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: Trump's national security advisors believed the president codename "MOGUL" was going to join the procession. UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: The chat log continues. Military aide has confirmed that he wants to walk. They are begging him to reconsider. Current route will be 15th to F, F to 6th, 6th to Penn. Penn to the Capitol. So this is happening.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: There's millions of us here. Don't let them hide to you.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: What was he going to do up there?

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Oh, vice president.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: After more than an hour on stage, the president wrapped up his speech this way.

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: We fight like hell. And if you don't fight like hell, you're not going to have a country anymore. So let's walk down Pennsylvania Avenue. I want to thank you all go. God bless you and God bless America.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Let's go.

utterances.speaker: HUTCHINSON
utterances.sentences: And everybody was making the movement back to the motorcade. I had overheard Mr. Meadows say to him that he was still working on getting off the record movement to the Capitol.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: What happened next, as Trump and Secret Service agent, Robert Bobby Engel got into the presidential limousine known as The Beast, was relayed to Hutchinson by Trump's Deputy Chief of Staff, Tony Ornato.

utterances.speaker: HUTCHINSON
utterances.sentences: When I returned to the White House, Tony proceeded to tell me that once the president had gotten into the vehicle with Bobby, he thought that they were going up to the Capitol. And when Bobby had relayed to him, we're not, you don't have the assets to do it. It's not secure. We're going back to the West Wing.The president had a very strong, a very angry response to that. Tony described him as being irate. The president said something to the effect of, I'm the effing president. Take me up to the Capitol now, to which Bobby responded, sir, we have to go back to the West Wing. The president reached up towards the front of the vehicle to grab at the steering wheel. Mr. Engel grabbed his arm, said, sir, you need to take your hand off the steering wheel. We're going back to the West Wing. We're not going to the Capitol.

utterances.speaker: ADAM KINZINGER, FORMER REPRESENTATIVE OF THE UNITED STATES
utterances.sentences: It's a shocking story. And we've now heard from at least a Washington D.C. detective, something very similar.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: The morning of January 6, what were your expectations for the day?

utterances.speaker: SARAH MATTHEWS, FORMER DEPUTY WHITE HOUSE PRESS SECRETARY
utterances.sentences: I think I woke up thinking that it was going to be a normal day. And I just thought that he was going to go out there and give a speech and that that would be it.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: Sarah Matthews is Donald Trump's former deputy White House press secretary, and was in the White House on January 6.

utterances.speaker: MATTHEWS
utterances.sentences: It was kind of quiet, to be honest, in the West Wing that morning at least.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: That quiet would not last long. After the speeches at the ellipse, the president returned to the White House and the rioters made their way to the Capitol.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: They bolt through, it's on.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: Already aware of the increasing violence, Trump went into the private dining room just off the Oval Office at 1

utterances.speaker: MAGGIE HABERMAN, CNN POLITICAL ANALYST
utterances.sentences: When Donald Trump is upset about what he is seeing, he reacts. He was not reacting here.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: For more than three hours, the president of the United States refused to call off the violent rioters who stormed the U.S. Capitol.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: He was watching television and admiring what he saw.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: (inaudible)

utterances.speaker: HABERMAN
utterances.sentences: You know, he was happy that the certification was delayed. There were myriad efforts to get him to issue some kind of a statement. Those did not work. He didn't make a single phone call to any member of his government.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: It is now officially a riot.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: At 1

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: Nine hours declaring it a riot.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: When D.C. police officially declared this a riot, Trump tweeted out a link to his speech on the ellipse. The very one that had helped incite that riot. Realizing the severity of the situation, White House Counsel, Pat Cipollone, rushed to Mark Meadows, the president's chief of staff.

utterances.speaker: HUTCHINSON
utterances.sentences: And I remember Pat saying to him something to the effect of, the rioters got to the Capitol mark. We need to get on and see the president now. And Mark looked up at and then said, he doesn't want to do anything, Pat.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: It's over. You better run, cops.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: Right as the violence surge, Trump tweeted, "Mike Pence didn't have the courage to do what should have been done to protect our country and our Constitution."

utterances.speaker: SARAH MATTHEWS, FORMER WHITE HOUSE DEPUTY PRESS SECRETARY FOR TRUMP
utterances.sentences: It was the last thing that was really needed in that moment. It pretty much painted a target on the vice president's back by tweeting that out.(CHANTING "HANG MIKE PENCE")

utterances.speaker: HUTCHINSON
utterances.sentences: I remember Pat saying something to the effect of, Mark, we need to do something more. They're literally calling for the vice president's be effing hang. And Mark had responded something to the effect of, you heard it, Pat. He thinks Mike deserves it.

utterances.speaker: MATTHEWS
utterances.sentences: Working in communications for president Trump, I was very aware of just the impact that his words have on his supporters. That tweet suggested to them that what they were doing at the Capitol was OK, and that they were justified in their violence, and that it was vice president Pence who was allowing an election to be stolen.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Mike Pence has betrayed this president and he has betrayed the people of the United States.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: Inside the Capitol, the Vice President was rushed from the Senate floor. Secret Service held Pence, along with his family and aides in his Senate office, as they work to clear a path to safety.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: If we lose any more time, we may have -- we may lose the ability to leave.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: A White House security official who chose to remain anonymous for fear of retaliation, explained exactly how dire the situation was for Pence and his Secret Service detail.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: The members of the VP detail at this time were starting to fear for their own lives. If they're running out of options, and they're getting nervous, it sounds like that we came very close to either service happened to use legal options or worse.[22:40:06] TAPPER: When the Secret Service made the call to move the vice president again, rioters came within 40 feet of him. As he was held in an undisclosed location, it was the vice president who directed a response to the riot. (CHANTING "STOP THE STEAL")

utterances.speaker: HUTCHINSON
utterances.sentences: It was Pence who was on the phone with these lawmakers. Pence who was on the phone with people in the Pentagon about what was -- what was happening with the National Guard.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: At 2By this point, rioters were in both chambers.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: This is our House.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: And the capitol rotunda was filled with tear gas.

utterances.speaker: MATTHEWS
utterances.sentences: At the end of the tweet, he used the phrase, stay peaceful. Kayleigh McEnany shared with me that he did not want to include that. And that it took a lot of convincing on their part. That was extremely alarming to me.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: The rioters were getting Trump's messages in real time, as heard on walkie-talkie communications between rioters.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Trump just tweeted, please support our Capitol police. They are on our side. Do not harm them.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: He didn't say not to do anything to the congressmen.

utterances.speaker: KAITLAN COLLINS, CNN HOST
utterances.sentences: I think what the committee showed about Trump's tweets is that they do take them literally. His messages were received by the people who were there at the Capitol very loudly.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: Any moment during the siege on the Capitol, the president could have addressed the country live from the White House.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: There's a camera on in the White House briefing room at all times. He could have walked over there, could have been on camera almost instantaneously, and blasted out a message to the American people. He had every opportunity and he chose to not do that.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: When the president finally relented and released a video telling the rioters to go home, it was 4

utterances.speaker: ADAM KINZINGER, FORMER REPRESENTATIVE OF THE UNITED STATES
utterances.sentences: It became very clear that the Feds basically had taken the Capitol back over, that they were not going to succeed in stopping the counting. And only then did he come out with that statement.

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: We had an election that was stolen from us. It was a landslide election. And everyone knows it.

utterances.speaker: MATTHEWS
utterances.sentences: Seeing him on camera, start the video by talking about a stolen election, I just immediately knew that he wasn't going to meet the moment and say what was needed in that time.

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: So go home. We love you. You're very special.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: Yet again, many rioters took the president's words as instructions.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: I'm here delivering the president's message.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: Donald Trump has asked everybody to go home.

utterances.speaker: MATTHEWS
utterances.sentences: Working in communications for him, I knew that I would be tasked with defending that. And we had just witnessed all this violence at the Capitol. And these folks attacking police officers chanting horrible things. And I knew that I couldn't defend that because it was indefensible. I resigned that evening.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: In the immediate aftermath of the riot as blood and broken glass littered the halls of Congress, according to the January 6 Committee, there were those who were still trying to overturn the election. That evening, Rudy Giuliani called a number of Republican senators and urged them to continue to try and delay the certification.

utterances.speaker: RUDY GIULIANI, FORMER TRUMP ATTORNEY
utterances.sentences: I'm calling you because I want to discuss with you how they're trying to rush this hearing.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: The next day John Eastman called White House Counsel, Eric Herschmann, to discuss an appeal in Georgia.

utterances.speaker: ERIC HERSCHMANN, FORMER WHITE HOUSE SENIOR ADVISOR TO TRUMP
utterances.sentences: I said to him, are you out of your effing mind? Now I'm going to give you the best free legal advice you're ever getting in your life. Get a great effing criminal defense lawyer, you're going to need it. And then I hung up on him.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: And the president released a second video condemning the violence more forcefully on January 7th.

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: Like all Americans, I am outraged by the violence, lawlessness and mayhem.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: But according to White House aide, Cassidy Hutchinson, it was only the threat of his cabinet invoking the 25th Amendment that convinced him to make this video. Advisors warned Trump that talk of removing him from office was gaining traction.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: And even then, he still refused to admit the election was over.

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: This election is now over. Congress has certified the results. I don't want to say the law the election is over. I just want to say Congress has certified the results without saying the election is over. OK?

utterances.speaker: LIZ CHENEY, FORMER REPRESENTATIVE OF THE UNITED STATES
utterances.sentences: That video just showed you that even after every single constitutional process had been completed, and after over 60 courts had heard his challenges and rejected them, he still refused, who's fundamentally a rejection of the rule of law.And again, America can't sustain itself if we have a commander in chief who is at war with the rule of law.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: Coming up.

utterances.speaker: KINZINGER
utterances.sentences: I want the American people to look at these hearings and understand how close we came that day to losing that self-governance.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: The battle to prevent another January 6.(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: What do you want Americans to take away from the hearings?

utterances.speaker: KINZINGER
utterances.sentences: I want the American people to look at these hearings and understand how close we came that day to losing that self-governance. Freedom isn't free. You have to defend this and not just overseas but sometimes here at home.(CHANTING "USA")

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: Do you miss me yet? Do you miss me?

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: In the aftermath of January 6 and his election loss --

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: Anthony Gonzalez, that's another beauty.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: -- Donald Trump made it his mission to replace Republican opponents with supporters. He had mixed success.In Arizona and Pennsylvania, he backed the gubernatorial candidates Kari Lake and Doug Mastriano. And Senate candidates, Blake Masters and Mehmet Oz, all of them lost. Of the 10 Republicans in the House of Representatives who voted to impeach Trump because of January 6, only to return to Congress in 2023. The others either declined to run for reelection such as Adam Kinzinger or lost the Republican primary reelection battles to more Trump supporting candidates, such as Liz Cheney.

utterances.speaker: CHENEY
utterances.sentences: That I will do whatever it takes.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: This mission that you've taken on has cost you your job. Do you have any regrets?

utterances.speaker: CHENEY
utterances.sentences: Our obligation, my obligation very much is above politics. I can't imagine having done anything differently at any stage of this process since January 6. It saddens me that so many of my Republican colleagues have not met the moment.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: Kinzinger and Cheney were the only two Republicans on the House Select Committee to investigate the attack on January 6. They become pariahs in a party where they were once seen as its future.

utterances.speaker: KINZINGER
utterances.sentences: We cannot survive as a party existing on the personality of one man.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: The Select Committee to investigate the January 6 attack had a Herculean task set before it. Its members and staff conducted more than 1,000 interviews, filmed hundreds of taped depositions and collected more than 140,000 documents.And finally, the week of December 19th, the committee showed us its full hand. Leading this hour, the January 6 Committee referring Donald Trump to the Justice Department for criminal prosecution.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: The first criminal statute we invoke for referral, therefore --

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: At its last hearing, the committee recommended Donald Trump be prosecuted for four different crimes, including obstruction of an official proceeding on January 6, 2021.REP. JAMIE RASKIN (D-MD): The whole purpose and obvious effect of Trump's scheme were to obstruct, influence, and impede this official proceeding.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: Conspiracy to defraud the United States, conspiracy to make false statements, and perhaps the most grave referral, the one for aiding or assisting an insurrection.

utterances.speaker: RASKIN
utterances.sentences: Anyone who incites others to engage in rebelling, assist them in doing so, where it gives aid and comfort to those engaged in insurrection is guilty of a federal crime.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: It's a charge that may be particularly difficult to prove. RICHARD DONOGHUE, FORMER U.S. ACTING DEPUTY ATTORNEY GENERALJ. MICHAEL LUTTIG, FORMER JUDGE OF THE UNITED STATES COURT OF APPEALS FOR THE FOURTH CIRCUIT: I said that --

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: Not everyone shares that view.

utterances.speaker: LUTTIG
utterances.sentences: Willful ignorance of fact or law by the President of the United States would not be either a legal defense or a political defense to the president. That's about as clear as a -- as a former judge could say it.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: Ultimately, the Justice Department will decide whether to bring any charges against former president Trump or John Eastman, who the committee also referred for criminal prosecution or anyone else.In November, Attorney General Merrick Garland appointed a former war crimes prosecutor named, Jack Smith, as special counsel, in charge of these ongoing investigations.

utterances.speaker: SARA MURRAY, CNN POLITICAL CORRESPONDENT
utterances.sentences: We know the Justice Department has been investigating Jeffrey Clark. We also know that John Eastman is someone who has been touched by this investigation.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: I'd like to see the warrant before you take my property.

utterances.speaker: GIULIANI
utterances.sentences: We will not talk about this until it's over.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: And appeared before a grand jury in August.At the moment, perhaps the most perilous investigation for Donald Trump has nothing to do with the attack on the Capitol.

utterances.speaker: SARA SIDNER, CNN HOST
utterances.sentences: Former President Donald Trump's Mar a Lago home in Florida, has been searched by the FBI.

utterances.speaker: HABERMAN
utterances.sentences: The investigation that at the moment seems most directly threatening to Donald Trump is the one to do his handling of classified documents and taking documents to Mar-a-Lago with him when he left office. TAPPERJustice Department investigations of Donald Trump are certain to be helped by the 845-page committee report, and the hundreds of documents and transcripts released by the January 6 Committee, as the Congress came to a close in 2022. Among the recommendations in the report --

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: The committee believes that those who took an oath to protect and defend the Constitution on January 6, shouldn't be barred, disqualified and barred from holding government office.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: President Donald --

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: That's aimed at Trump, who has already announced he's running for president in 2024, something that committee has said, should not be allowed.

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: I'm thrilled to be back.

utterances.speaker: CHENEY
utterances.sentences: No man who would behave that way, at that moment in time, can ever serve in any position of authority in our nation again. He is unfit for any office.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: Among the thousands of pages of transcripts released by the committee, were new bits of information, including Cassidy Hutchinson's claim that she saw Trump's chief of staff, Mark Meadows, burn documents in his White House fireplace about a dozen times during the transition.

utterances.speaker: GLORIA BORGER, CNN CHIEF POLITICAL ANALYST
utterances.sentences: Even Richard Nixon didn't burn the tapes. There was a gap, but he didn't burn the tapes.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: Also, in those pages, claims from Hutchinson that Meadows told her the president knew he lost the 2020 election, despite what he was saying publicly.Does the President really think that he lost? Hutchinson asked Meadows on one occasion. He said, you know, a lot of times they'll tell me that he lost, but he wants to keep fighting it. How much the committee hearings and findings have impacted the country's view of Trump remains unclear.

utterances.speaker: HABERMAN
utterances.sentences: I think the January 6 hearings actually presented a pretty concise case. And I do think that it got through to voters. And I think it was partly because it was Trump's own appointees, Republican appointees, who were the ones they used to testify against him, whether that lingers in voter's minds, I think is a real open question. COLLINS

utterances.speaker: SIDNER
utterances.sentences: Is any of this new revelations from these transcripts, enough to loosen Donald Trump's grip on the Republican Party You think?

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: I doubt it, not in his base. His base is going to stay where they are. They don't care about the facts.

utterances.speaker: LUTTIG
utterances.sentences: Donald Trump and his supporters are a clear and present danger to American democracy.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: You've been shouting from the rooftops. This is not just about 2020, you're worried about 2024.

utterances.speaker: LUTTIG
utterances.sentences: I am. And right now, the former president and his allies and supporters, including in Congress, and including in the states, represent a clear and present danger to American democracy. That's not because of what they did on January 6, is because of what they pledged to do in 2024.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: Do you think that Republicans are hearing what you're saying?

utterances.speaker: LUTTIG
utterances.sentences: I hope they are.
